sect2.title: 12.1 Introduction
sect2.para: When a patient’s quality of life significantly declines and suffering is expected, the veterinary team has the option to perform euthanasia. Administering euthanasia solution has been described as the ultimate palliation to relieve pain, breathing difficulty, anxiety, etc., with the side effect being deathch0024-c12-bib-0001. In other words, the only permanent way to release an animal from suffering before their natural death is euthanasia. This view of euthanasia as the ultimate form of palliation can change the way we perceive the drugs and methods we use.

When the difficult decision to euthanize a beloved pet has been made, the veterinary team must then decide which euthanasia method is most suitable. Over many decades, veterinarians and animal welfare experts have developed safe and effective means of ending life. For companion animals, the most common method is the injection of pentobarbital sodium ch0024-c12-bib-0002. As mentioned in Chapter 11, pentobarbital is an anesthetic drug that elicits its effects on the brain through an overdose, which shuts down communication between the brain and the body. When properly dosed, pentobarbital is ultrafast acting and can be relied on to end an animal’s life with minimal side effects (see Figure 12.1). The common injection sites include the veins (intravenous‐IV), the heart (intracardiac‐IC), the liver (intrahepatic‐IH), the kidney (intrarenal‐IR), and the abdomen (intraperitoneal‐IP).

The lack of side effects is what makes pentobarbital attractive for use in companion animal euthanasia. Caregivers can become concerned when witnessing active signs of death in their pet, and believe their pet is struggling/sufferingch0024-c12-bib-0003. Veterinary teams must consider the optics of death along with other factors to determine the best euthanasia method.

Table 12.1 lists factors to consider when selecting an appropriate euthanasia technique for a patient. The veterinary professional (usually a veterinarian) selecting the euthanasia technique will need to consider all of these factors collectively, as they all have a bearing on the success of the procedure. For example, a large dog with osteosarcoma (bone cancer) is not the ideal candidate for an IP injection of pentobarbital. Due to the dog’s size, it may take considerably longer for death to be achieved, and the veterinary team may not have enough solution to properly dose. A cat with liver disease is not the best fit for an IH injection, conducted by a veterinarian who has never performed it before, in a room full of family members who have requested a postmortem necropsy. Infusing pentobarbital into the liver has the potential to alter necropsy results, and the added stress of properly performing the procedure for the first time with a room full of people may not be necessary. These examples illustrate the importance of weighing the pros and cons of each euthanasia technique before starting.

Veterinary technicians familiar with alternative euthanasia techniques may offer valuable advice to the team, especially when some team members are unfamiliar with modern euthanasia methodology. Knowledge of multiple technique options lays the foundation for a more controlled and constructive euthanasia appointment. Technicians can help determine the best technique given the situation and have backup technique supplies ready, including some of the alternatives that will be described later. In some instances, it may be possible and even preferable for animal welfare for the veterinarian to direct a technician to administer euthanasia. This would typically be a situation where the veterinarian determines that urgent euthanasia is required and the technician is able to provide it significantly sooner (i.e. the veterinarian is in surgery for a prolonged period, or at another urgent house call). This was also briefly discussed inChapters 10 and 11. Technicians administering euthanasia without a veterinarian on‐site may not be possible in all regions due to issues regarding controlled substance handling and transport ch0024-c12-bib-1004. Where permissible and under the direction of a veterinarian, mobilizing technicians to administer urgent welfare‐related euthanasia can help to relieve suffering in EOL patients.

While this chapter focuses on euthanasia techniques for small animals, large companion animals such as horses and livestock need to be mentioned. The larger the animal, the more care needs to be provided for their safety and that of those around them during death. A useful resource to learn more about the euthanasia of large animals is the book Veterinary Euthanasia Techniques; A Practical Guide (ed. Cooney et al. 2012).

sect2.title: 12.2 Euthanasia Injection Techniques
sect2.para: For the purposes of this section, only pentobarbital euthanasia injections will be described, however, veterinary teams are encouraged to use the most modern and effective euthanasia agents available to them. Many of these suggestions apply to any euthanasia technique/agent but technicians and veterinarians should always be sure before proceeding.

Pentobarbital or pentobarbital‐combination products are administered into the patient’s body to achieve an anesthetic overdose. Every injection route has its pros and cons (Table 12.2). The veterinarian and technician will decide which method is best suited to the patient based on their experience, available equipment, and the patient’s signalment including details such as blood pressure (BP) and body condition. The goal is to rapidly deliver enough drugs to the patient to cause death without the possibility of recovery. If pentobarbital is underdosed, the patient may regain consciousness in a few hours, so proper dosing is extremely important.

Intraorgan injections require patient unconsciousness. Patients must not feel pain during the administration of any type of euthanasia solution. This is accomplished by giving appropriate doses of pre‐euthanasia anesthesia using a drug combination that includes ketamine, tiletamine, alfaxalone, or other available anesthetics including gases (e.g. isoflurane). Technicians will verify that the patient is insensible to deep pain and the intra‐organ injection may be delivered.

sect2.para: Caregivers will need to be informed about the location of the injection in their pet’s body. The general location is sufficient, meaning it is unnecessary to describe precise details about why that injection location is being selected.

Too much information can overwhelm the caregiver and not enough can raise concerns. One option is to lay a hand over the injection site to indicate where the euthanasia “medicine” will be given (seeFigure 12.2). Technicians will hone their descriptions to match what’s important to their clients (Communication Corner 12.1).

sect2.title: 12.2.1 Intravenous (IV) Injections
sect2.para: Euthanasia solution may be given into any vein. Veins are located in every region of the body, both superficially near the skin and more internally. It does not matter which vein is used as long as it can be successfully injected, and the caregiver is allowed to remain close to their pet. In general, veterinarians and technicians prefer to distance themselves from the patient’s head and upper body area, choosing instead to work with veins around the back half of the body. This allows caregivers to be more intimately positioned near the front.

The most common veins to use in dogs and cats are the cephalic and saphenous veins. The cephalic vein resides on the cranial side of the forelimb, while the saphenous veins are in the hindlimb. In dogs, the lateral saphenous vein runs from the tarsus up the lateral side of the lower leg to behind the knee. Distal to it is the dorsal pedal vein on the dorsal surface of the hind foot. In cats, the medial saphenous vein is found in the medial thigh region. Other veins include the ventral abdominal vein, the jugular vein, superficial ear vein, and the tongue vein, none of which are commonly used in dogs and cats but are nevertheless available.

The standard pentobarbital dose for IV injections is between 85 and 107 mg/kg (doses vary by country). The necessary volume of the drug will be administered steadily into the vein. IV administration is fast and reliable, with visual cues of death often starting before the injection is complete (e.g. deep breaths, slight leg stretches, and tail raising). The time to death (TTD) is expected in under two minutes, with most animals passing in under one minute. As long as the entirety of the pentobarbital dose is properly administered into the vein, euthanasia will be swift and permanent.

Technicians will inject a vein one of three ways, either via direct venipuncture, a butterfly catheter, or an indwelling IV catheter. When a patient is sleeping after the administration of a pre‐euthanasia sedative/anesthetic, the method by which the vein is injected becomes less important. The patient is sleeping and unlikely to move/react. However, if the patient is awake the placement of an indwelling IV catheter is strongly encouraged ch0024-c12-bib-0002. It’s good to standardize the injection method the team prefers so that supplies are readily available. This author prefers to place an indwelling IV catheter for all IV injections, regardless of whether the patient is awake or sleeping. Once the catheter is placed, the caregivers may take as much time as they like to say goodbyes, and the vet team has less worry about falling BP. In other words, placing an IV catheter reduces the tendency to move quickly through the procedure.

sect2.title: 12.2.2 Intracardiac (IC) Injections
sect2.para: The heart is essentially a large blood vessel with thicker muscle around it. The heart can be used to deliver euthanasia solutions just as effectively as any vein in the body. The heart is closer to the brain than peripheral veins, therefore the solution has less distance to travel to render its effects. As mentioned inChapter 11, pentobarbital works directly on the brain to first induce unconsciousness, then respiratory arrest, and cardiac arrest. The dose of euthanasia solution for an IC injection is the same as IV, further demonstrating the similarity to venous injections.

Intracardiac injections require the patient to be completely unconscious before attempting. Once in a surgical plane of anesthesia, they are typically laid in lateral recumbency on a comfortable surface such as the caregiver’s lap or on a soft mat. The heart is found within the thoracic cavity, through a few key locating points: by feeling the chest wall for beats, by placing the point of the elbow (olecranon) in a standing position against the chest, by looking for the 3–6 intercostal rib spaces, and by listening to the point of maximum intensity (PMI) of the heartbeat. The needle is usually inserted into the lateral thoracic wall, aimed internally to reach the heart (Pro Tip 12.1).

sidebar.title: Pro Tip 12.1 Heartbeat Palpation for IC Injections
sidebar.para: Feeling the heartbeat with one’s hand is often enough to successfully locate the heart, thus reducing the need to count ribs, move the front leg, and pull out the stethoscope.

sect2.para:
Any chamber within the heart may be injected. The goal is to locate a substantial “flash” of blood in the syringe or extension set to indicate the heart has been found and the injection can begin. When this flash is seen, it means the tip of the needle is properly placed somewhere within the heart. A slow injection of euthanasia solution can begin, keeping a steady hand to protect the needle’s placement in the heart. If there is concern about proper placement, the syringe’s plunger can be pulled back slightly mid‐injection to check for another flash of blood in the syringe. If no blood
is seen, the injection may continue until all solution has been given, and another dose drawn up to give again. The expected outcome is to observe first the cessation of breathing, followed by stoppage of the heart. When properly performed, the IC injection TTD is under two minutes. If the heart continues to beat, give more drugs.

A study in 2023 found that many veterinarians try to avoid IC injections in front of caregiversch0024-c12-bib-0004. This is due to the likelihood that caregivers will see the flash of blood in the syringe, which may be upsetting to them. This visualization can be avoided by using a short extension set between the needle and syringe that allows the syringe to be lowered out of sight. Another option is to use the direct needle and syringe method but from the ventral approach rather than the lateral approach (see Figures 12.4–12.6). By reducing the sight of blood during IC injections, hopefully, veterinary teams will feel more comfortable using this technique and allow caregivers to remain present for the entirety of the procedure.

listitem.para: The heart is usually more cranial and ventral than one might think. Start there.
Be ready to draw back blood, air, or thoracic fluid. Use a larger syringe than what’s needed to hold the euthanasia solution.

sect2.title: 12.2.3 Intrarenal (IR) Injections
sect2.para: Administering pentobarbital into the kidney is becoming one of the most common methods in small animals, especially felines and small mammals [ch0024-c12-bib-0005, ch0024-c12-bib-0006]. The kidney has adequate blood flow, even with diseases such as chronic kidney disease and hydronephrosis, to move the drug up to the brain to achieve death. IR injections reduce the need to locate veins in thin, frail, and dehydrated patients such as older cats and those commonly seen in end‐of‐life (EOL) care. Veterinary teams often worry about IV injections in patients with poor health and may find great relief knowing an alternative like the IR method is possible.

The kidneys reside in the abdomen just ventral to the spine. The left kidney in cats sits outside of the retroperitoneal space making them easier to locate and hold in position. The right kidney sits slightly more cranial under the last rib. Either kidney may be injected. The key to a successful injection is the ability to hold the kidney in position and feel it swell as the solution is injected. This is achieved by first feeling for the kidney in the abdomen, then placing one’s fingertips slightly around it, and injecting slowly to feel for swelling (seeFigure 12.7).

figure.title:
Figure 12.7
Intrarenal injection in the left kidney of a feline patient. Source: Courtesy of CAETA.

textobject.phrase: A person is trimming a matted cat's fur with scissors.

sect2.para: The IR pentobarbital dose is currently set at 255 mg/kg ch0024-c12-bib-0002. This is three times the IV or IC dose, meaning more solution needs to be given into the kidney to achieve rapid death. Any needle gauge will do (this author prefers a 1‐in., 18‐gauge needle), and an extension set connected to the syringe is unnecessary and can even make the injection harder to accomplish. A direct needle and syringe approach is preferred. Swelling occurs as the result of increased pressure against the renal capsule before the euthanasia solution has time to move into the renal veins. Kidney swelling is the number one indicator that the solution has been properly injected, and it can be felt just after the start of the injection ch0024-c12-bib-0005. In time, we may find that the IR dose of pentobarbital can be decreased, although the injection of more solution increases the odds of proper renal cortex placement and subsequent swelling.

When performed correctly, TTD for IR injections is under one minute. The renal veins are like a superhighway moving the solution quickly to the heart and then up to the brain. Technicians will monitor the patient’s breathing, and if it continues longer than two minutes or so, another injection can be given although not necessary. As with all pentobarbital euthanasia methods, the cessation of breathing is the hallmark sign that death is approaching, and cardiac arrest will soon follow if an adequate dose is given. When a second injection is warranted, it can be given in the same kidney, or the other one may be used. The administrator needs to decide which kidney can be held in position long enough to give a full dose of pentobarbital and to feel the swelling. This said, it is possible to achieve death without feeling the kidney swell, but it is less common. A lack of swelling may indicate the kidney has been missed and the euthanasia solution is going into surrounding tissues with reduced blood flow (e.g. the abdomen), or the needle is inserted into the renal pelvis which delivers urine, and in this case euthanasia solution, into the bladder. The renal pelvis is avoided by aiming the needle into the renal cortical tissue.

listitem.para: Feel for the kidneys when the patient is succumbing to anesthesia. When they can be readily located, one can feel confident using them. If not, another method should be considered.
If the kidney does not swell at the onset of the injection, redirect the needle a bit and inject until swelling is felt.
Start the injection slowly to ensure your patient is unconscious with no response. After 0.5 ml is given with no visible reaction, continue with the rest of the injection.

If the kidney slips away mid‐injection, finish injecting in the general area of the kidney, then obtain more solution and try again or switch to the other kidney. The injection can also be moved to the liver or heart.
Monitor the breathing during the injection. Properly placed, properly dosed IR injections often lead to respiratory arrest before all solutions have been administered.

sect2.title: 12.2.4 Intrahepatic (IH) Injections
sect2.para: The goal of IH injections is to infuse euthanasia solution into the liver in the hopes of rapid uptake. The liver is a large organ and highly vascular, but this does not guarantee a quicker death. Compared to IC and IR, the TTD with IH injection is more variable, ranging from almost immediate up to 10 minutes or more. The large size of the liver and recognizable injection landmarks make it an attractive option for practitioners. The pentobarbital dose is 170 mg/kg meaning more solution will be given compared to IV and IC.

The liver is located caudal to the diaphragm and under the last few ribs on the ventral side of the abdomen. The injection point is on either side of the xyphoid process, the most caudal sternal vertebrae. The tip of the xyphoid is easy to feel on the ventral midline between the chest and the abdomen. Dogs, cats, and most exotic species have this landmark. A diseased liver may be larger or smaller in size but so far this has not dictated a change to the injection approach.

figure.title:
Figure 12.8
A cat receiving an intrahepatic injection with needle inserted next to the xyphoid process. Source: Courtesy of CAETA.

textobject.phrase: A person administers liquid medication to a white cat using a syringe.

sect2.para: To reach the liver, a longer needle is necessary. A good starting point is a 1.5–2‐in. needle, however, some veterinary teams report using 3‐in. needles as their standard. It will depend on the patient's size. The needle is inserted at a 45°, with the tip of the needle aimed cranially (seeFigure 12.8). It is helpful to picture the needle exiting the body near the base of the neck by the shoulder blades if it were long enough to extend that far (see Figure 12.9). The needle can be placed directly on the syringe, or a short extension set used to extend the syringe a bit further away from the body.

The injection should be started slowly in anesthetized patients, to ensure there is no patient response. After approximately 0.5 ml of solution has been given with no response, the injection speed may be increased but continued slow administration is perfectly acceptable. Ideally, the patient’s breathing pattern starts to change mid‐injection, indicating it is already reaching the brain. The administrator can give the entire volume of euthanasia solution in one spot, or they can redirect the needle around to effectively “bathe” the liver in the drug in the hopes of speeding uptake. There is no data that shows this shortens TTD, however there may be some merit to increasing the absorption zone.

figure.title:
Figure 12.9
Demonstration of the proper angle for an intrahepatic injection. Administrators may imagine the needle would exit between the shoulder blades if long enough. Source: Courtesy of CAETA.

textobject.phrase: A hand pets a white cat lying on a green towel.

sect2.para: If breathing continues at a normal rate after completion of the injection, another injection can be given immediately, or time provided for the drug to absorb into the vasculature. It can be unsettling to wait for cardiac arrest, especially when one is unsure if the liver was properly injected. There are other structures nearby that may have been injected (e.g. gallbladder, stomach, spleen, fat, and free abdomen) that slow TTD. When in doubt, it is always acceptable to give a second or third injection.

listitem.para: Avoid this technique when large amounts of abdominal fat and/or fluid are suspected. It is likely to slow absorption and TTD.
Start the injection slowly to ensure your patient is unconscious with no response. After 0.5 ml is given with no visible reaction, continue with the rest of the injection.
Large dogs require a longer needle. Keep a few 3–4‐in. needles on hand.
Insert the needle to the hub, unless it’s a small patient with an extra‐long needle.

You may draw back the syringe to check for blood or other fluid; however, it may not indicate if you are properly placed in the liver. If a large flash of blood is observed, inject. You may be within an internal vessel and that is beneficial.

sect2.title: 12.2.5 Intraperitoneal (IP) Injections
sect2.para: The IP technique is unique among the others for two main reasons. The first reason is that it requires the use of a pentobarbital euthanasia solution and none of the other alternative agents (e.g. potassium chloride, magnesium sulfate, and lidocaine). As of 2024, no other drugs/agents have been identified as reliable and irreversible when given into the abdomen of dogs and cats, especially when caregivers are presentch0024-c12-bib-0002. The second reason is that IP injections take longer to achieve death compared to IV or intra‐organ injections. On average, a patient will succumb to the effects of the drug between 10 and 20 minutes ch0024-c12-bib-0007. This author has had IP injections 45 minutes before death. The current IP dose of pentobarbital is 255 mg/kg.

The common use of pre‐euthanasia sedatives/anesthetics in animal hospice reduces the likelihood of IP injections being used. Intra‐organ injections shorten the TTD and are generally preferred. However, there will be times when pre‐euthanasia sedatives/anesthetics are not used, and IP injections of pentobarbital are given to awake EOL patients. This is most likely to be decided on a case‐by‐case basis by the attending veterinarian and team. It’s possible that the IP technique is the preferred method for technicians to perform due to the relative ease of administration.

There are a few injection sites to safely place pentobarbital euthanasia solution in the abdomen. The goal is to miss organs like the spleen, intestine, bladder, and abdominal fat stores which will slow absorption and potentially cause pain. A needle may be inserted perpendicular to the body wall, near the ventral midline, just caudal to the umbilicus, and a little to the right side. Other injection locations include the flank region on the right or left side of the abdomen, below the spinal musculature, although the right side is more reliablech0024-c12-bib-0007. Avoiding the stomach and spleen on the left side of the abdomen is preferred. Once the needle has penetrated through the body wall, the syringe plunger should be drawn back to check for negative pressure and absence of fluids like accidental stomach content and urine. If nothing is found, the injection may begin.

Generally, IP injections in awake animals are believed to be non‐painful or at least tolerable to the patient when compared to intramuscular injections of low pH drugs such as ketamine [ch0024-c12-bib-0008, ch0024-c12-bib-0009]. Technicians may still observe patient discomfort and should be prepared to address it if caregivers voice concerns. Following the injection, patients should be kept close by and monitored as they begin anesthetizing with pentobarbital. It is possible for them to be unstable and even vocalize as they move through the early stages of anesthesia. Patients should be kept calm, in quiet areas with minimal stimulation. Once the patient becomes unconscious, another injection of pentobarbital may be given into an organ to shorten the TTD if desired.

listitem.para: Avoid this method unless the patient must remain awake (no pre‐euthanasia drugs available) and IV access is difficult (e.g. exotics).
If TTD is taking longer than 15 minutes, give another injection in an organ to speed up uptake. The patient should be anesthetized by this time.
Have extra pentobarbital ready.
This method is best reserved for small patients under 12 kg.

sect2.title: 12.3.1 Oral Administration of Euthanasia Drugs
sect2.para: There are instances when avoiding injections is better for the patient. It is possible to give some euthanasia solutions (namely pentobarbital) orally to be fully ingested or to be absorbed by the oral mucosa [ch0024-c12-bib-0006, ch0024-c12-bib-0010–ch0024-c12-bib-0013]. Ideally, a lethal dose is administered and directly causes death. However, it is possible to use some euthanasia drugs orally to induce unconsciousness, followed shortly after with an injection when the patient is no longer responsive. Successfully feeding euthanasia solution depends on the patient’s hunger levels, the taste of the drug, and the ability to entice a dying patient to eat. In this author’s experience having tried oral euthanasia solutions many times, heavy sedation/anesthesia is more common than achieving death, although soon‐to‐be‐released research may prove differently.

sect2.title: 12.3.2 Intrathecal Anesthetic Euthanasia
sect2.para: Drugs such as lidocaine and mepivacaine are evolving into euthanasia agents when they are deemed more appropriate than pentobarbital or others [ch0024-c12-bib-0013, ch0024-c12-bib-0014]. These anesthetic drugs can be given into the spinal column as anesthetic overdoses to induce death in under 10 minutes (see Figure 12.10). Patients must be given pre‐euthanasia anesthetics such as ketamine to induce unconsciousness before a spinal tap begins. Technicians familiar with the spinal tap procedure may be able to assist or perform this technique under the right conditions. Intrathecal anesthetic euthanasia of a nonbarbiturate drug is beneficial when caregivers wish to bury their pet (see Chapter 13) or when other drugs are not available.

sect2.title: 12.3.3 Physical Methods of Euthanasia
sect2.para: While extremely rare in this author’s experience, physical euthanasia methods may be necessary for companion animal EOL patients, including dogs and cats. Physical methods work by either destroying brain tissue (e.g. gunshot) or via anoxia from methods such as exsanguination (requires that unconsciousness has already been induced). These methods are most useful when euthanasia agents cannot be given, and patient suffering is present. When caregivers are present, extreme care must be taken to help them understand how the physical method works, what they will see, and how they may interact with their pet, if at all, due to safety concerns.

sect2.title: 12.3.4 Euthanizing Fetuses
sect2.para: Scientific study shows that embryos and fetuses cannot experience pain and breathlessness during pregnancy and cannot suffer while dying in utero after the death of the dam, whatever the causech0024-c12-bib-0015. Once a first breath is taken following birth, they are considered sentient and may experience pain, therefore appropriate euthanasia techniques should be used. Pregnant bitches and queens may be euthanized via proper IV or IC euthanasia solution injection with the death of the fetuses occurring naturally from anesthetic overdose or hypoxia soon afterward. This may take up to 15–20 minutes after the mother is confirmed dead ch0024-c12-bib-0002. IP injections of pentobarbital should be avoided during the later stages of pregnancy as the uterus may be accidentally injected. However, IP injections are perfectly acceptable for newborns because venous access can be very difficult. It may be necessary to euthanize fetuses still within the uterus during caesarian section of the pregnant bitch or queen. This can be safely accomplished by clamping the uterine blood vessels, thus allowing the fetuses to die by hypoxia.

sect2.title: 12.4 Physical Changes During Death and Pronouncing Death
sect2.para: Death is a dynamic event, meaning that people will see physical changes to the animal’s body as it ceases to function (seeTable 12.3). This is normal and expected. Technicians who understand these changes can describe them to observers in the immediate area. Technicians may explain what’s being seen in simple phrases while keeping the dying animal safe during the transition from life to death, which is what caregivers ultimately want. A “less is more” approach to the description of death is appropriate, especially when caregivers feel confident that the veterinary team has everything under control. More details can be shared if caregivers ask (Communication Corner 12.2).

Potential physical signs of death.

sidebar.title: Communication Corner 12.2 Example Language to Explain Physical Changes
sidebar.para: (remembering that explanations to caregivers are not always necessary)

listitem.para: “These breaths are reflexive. He has died and is now releasing energy.”
“Yes, her body is releasing some urine. Very natural. I’ll keep her dry with this towel placed underneath.”
“His eyes have remained open. This is normal. We can permanently close them if you wish or leave them naturally open as they are now.”

emphasis.emphasis: Example Language to Pronounce the Patient Deceased

listitem.para: “His heart has stopped, and he has died.”
“There is no more heartbeat. He has died.”
“Her heart is quiet, and death is complete.”
“She has died.”

sect2.para: The eyes will show changes including corneal glazing and pupil dilation, the third eyelid may move, or the eyelids themselves may close or open. In this author’s experience, reptiles and birds often close their eyelids during anesthesia and death. If a patient dies with their eyes open, it is acceptable to leave them open or the technician may gently attempt to close them using their fingers. At the caregiver’s request, permanent eye closing can be done using skin adhesive glue along the edge of the eyelids.

When the veterinarian or technician confirms that death has arrived, they may pronounce death. It is important to verbally pronounce a patient deceased when other people are in the area. It can be hard for loved ones to hear, but nevertheless, a formal declaration that permanent death has been achieved is part of the experience. This will be done by the veterinary professional performing the euthanasia. They may decide exactly how to pronounce death, but because euthanasia is a medical procedure it is advisable to use clear language without euphemisms that may confuse the listener. Taking a deep, relaxing breath before and after pronouncing the patient deceased can help to calm nervous tension in the room.

sect2.title: 12.5 Exotic Pet Considerations
sect2.para: Working with exotic pets offers an opportunity to provide the same loving care and attention to gentle death. Caregivers can show as much affection for exotic pets as they do the more traditional dogs and catsch0024-c12-bib-0016. Compassionate technicians will acknowledge the love that caregivers have for their exotic pets. The approach to euthanasia and respect for the bond will be the same regardless of species. We offer privacy before, during, and after euthanasia, we provide the same appointment length, and we give bereavement support.

In this author’s experience, caregivers grieve similarly for exotic pets and the desire for euthanasia to go smoothly is the same as it is for dogs and cats. The difference tends to be in the level of understanding of how exotic pet euthanasia is carried out. Many caregivers will be familiar with what dog euthanasia looks like but have never experienced it with an exotic pet. This means technicians will need to set aside time to describe the procedure in greater detail, thus reducing fears of the unknown.

Common exotic pet species that will require euthanasia services include birds, reptiles, amphibians, fish, and small mammalsch0024-c12-bib-0017. Caregivers may own other species where less is known about their anatomy and physiology, making them more challenging to euthanize. As with any animal, the veterinary team will want to ensure they know how to safely and permanently euthanize before attempting. This requires some basic knowledge of the anatomy and physiology of the species in question, which will help to inform the choice of euthanasia technique.

Veterinary practices located near a clinic that routinely sees exotic pets may refer to that practice, but not all communities have this resource available to them. Veterinary technicians that learn how to offer humane euthanasia to exotic species can support compassionate EOL care for caregivers of pets who may have nowhere else to turn. With that in mind, a summary of some basic guidance and tips for exotic pet euthanasia is included here as an introduction only. Veterinary teams wishing to offer exotic pet euthanasia routinely should seek out continuing education on this topic and have resources on hand in their practice for quick reference (Pro Tip 12.2). This is particularly important when selecting drug doses and routes, the details of which go beyond the scope of this chapter. Personnel safety is also an important consideration, as exotic species may present risks that teams are less familiar with. Technicians must have a plan that includes safe handling techniques and tools before taking on exotic cases.

sect2.title: 12.5.1 General Considerations for Patient Comfort
sect2.para: Technicians should reflect on what is normal for the species and try to support and maintain this as much as possible through the euthanasia experience. Instinct refers to what’s natural to the exotic pet patient and evolved for the animal’s preservation. For example, if an animal wants to nest and avoid physical contact, the technician should follow its lead. They can shift their approach and euthanize in the environment the animal prefers. Burrowing animals can be wrapped in a thin blanket/wrap and a medicine injection is given through it. If you must remove the animal from its habitat to give the medications, place them right back in so they may die in safe surroundings.

With nocturnal species, there may be an opportunity to work with them at the start of the workday, right before they would typically go to sleep after a busy night. Many species prefer quiet spaces with minimal talking. They like safe and recognizable structures nearby too. Technicians can advocate for keeping exotic pets in their home cages, nesting pouches, or other structures. Home euthanasia is also another important consideration, especially for species accustomed to remaining in their cages/habitats.

The general rule with exotic pet euthanasia is to go slow and take extra time. Caregivers should know that death may take longer than what they may be used to and that a fast death does not equal a good death, especially when unpleasant restraint is used (e.g. forcing an animal into an unnatural position during euthanasia). Patient comfort is of utmost importance (seeFigure 12.11).

Technicians should provide pre‐euthanasia sedation to all exotic pets just as is recommended in other companion animals. Administering pre‐euthanasia anesthesia is preferred in most exotic patients as this allows more flexibility in technique choices (e.g. IC injections and brain pithing) (Table 12.4). Oral drug administration for sedation can be effective in many exotic species and may be less stressful for pets and caregivers than injections

Deceased bodies will need to be handled similar to dogs and cats, especially when pentobarbital is used (this will be discussed further inChapter 13). In some cases, a more rigid container may be required for transporting the deceased pet to protect handlers from dangers still present after death, such as talons or venom. Aftercare discussions and options for exotic pets should mirror those for canine and feline patients. Paw prints and fur clippings are often easily acquired, but other alternatives may be similarly appreciated such as imprints of scales, scutes, noses, or muzzles.

sect2.title: 12.6 Unique Circumstances
sect2.para: Most euthanasia procedures that follow an appropriate standard of care will be straightforward. The EOL patient’s comfort is in question, and the decision is made to euthanize. The sick pet will be given sedatives/anesthetics to bring about sleep, the euthanasia solution is administered, and the heart stops. The more a technician participates in euthanasia, the more familiar they become and the more confident they feel to manage challenges that arise. From time to time, unique circumstances may present. The following items assume the use of pentobarbital as the euthanasia agent.

sidebar.title: Communication Corner 12.3 Sample Language to Use When the Heart Keeps Beating Longer Than Expected

emphasis.emphasis: These statements should be said with great tenderness

listitem.para: “We will wait for the medicine to work. This is his day so we will go at his pace.”
“The medicine works on the brain. We will be patient as it takes effect.”
“Let’s go ahead and give a bit more to ensure it gets to the brain to help her to pass.”
“Her body tells me she could use a bit more. This is her day, whatever she needs.”

sidebar.title: Communication Corner 12.4 Sample Language to Use When Active Death Signs may be Alarming

listitem.para: “Her body is releasing energy. This is very natural.”
“She’s embracing the change. We are right here supporting her.”
“He is unaware of any physical changes. This is normal even with natural death.”
“Each one passes in their own way. Our role is to support and love them.”

The heart keeps beating: If the heart keeps beating after the proper dose of euthanasia solution has been given, it likely means the brain has not been overdosed. The options are to give more time for the vasculature to move the drug to the brain, or to give more euthanasia solution. Depending on the injection method, it’s acceptable to wait up to five minutes after an IV, IC, or IR injection before redosing. IH and IP injections can take longer to elicit death, so waiting 10 minutes or more is acceptable (Communication Corner 12.3).

Very active death: The body is experiencing a profound electrical change during euthanasia. Some of the associated physical reactions will be subtle while others will be very noticeable and even alarming to see (e.g. opisthotonos stretching, vocalization, large muscle fasciculations, agonal breathing, and paddling). While the veterinary team understands and is familiar with these events, the caregiver may need to be reassured that everything is normal, and their pet is safe (Communication Corner 12.4). This includes when seizures (very rare) present while the patient is actively dying. If the patient’s mouth is making biting motions, technicians will want to make sure caregivers’ hands are out of harm’s way.
Utilize the best technique based on the patient’s signalment and available supplies.
Go slow and be patient. Death does not have to be fast to be successful.
Caregivers should be allowed to be present for the entirety of the procedure.
Improve patient comfort by inducing either pre‐euthanasia sedation or complete unconsciousness (dependent on the type of technique used).
Challenges may arise. Take a deep breath and proceed calmly.
